What I meant was, as in my own case, I use my left hand for eating, writing
and using small tools like scissors, but I play all sports with my right
hand. I do not think that your typical right-handed person does that. 

 

Gordon

Gordon,

>I might add that to the best of my knowledge there is no such thing as an
entirely left-handed person. Left-handed individuals either due to nurture
or nature seem to do some things with the right-hand and others with the
left and sometimes able to use both for the same thing.<

By that criteria, there are no entirely right-handed people, either,
barring amputees or people with equivalent medical conditions. After
all, my left hand/arm doesn't hang useless at my side. I use it for
lots of things.

Best Regards,

Hi John,



If you refer to the Tokyo National Museum's publication on Uchigatana
Koshirae, you will note several Tensho period mounts arranged for wear
on
the right side. There is some question as to whether or not they were
for
wear with the cutting edge down. I don't know of any illustrations
showing
right handed wear. I might add that to the best of my knowledge there is
no
such thing as an entirely left-handed person. Left-handed individuals
either
due to nurture or nature seem to do some things with the right-hand and
others with the left and sometimes able to use both for the same thing.



Gordon

To inject a slightly more serious note into the smugness of your
'leftie'
members ... 

Do any members KNOW if left-handedness was extant among early Japanese
swordsmen.  I have never, personally, seen illustrations of samurai
wearing
their swords on the right side, and it is not inconceivable that they
were
trained at an early age to use their swords in the conventional manner. 
The
only advantage in being left handed is, surely, its comparative rarity
and
strangeness to a right-handed opponent.

Interestingly, I have in my collection (WAY 386.27.ex Gardiner
collection)
an unsigned,  shakudo fuchi-gashira, attributed to Hirata Harunari  This
has
an ishime surface, with takaramono in a shippo of coloured enamels
within
gold cloissons.  The ura surface of the fuchi has had an additional
takaramono added in gold lacquer, and this may possibly be to facilitate
its
wearing on the right side by presenting a more decorative surface.  I
can
think of no other possible explanation for this modification.

John L.
